Goldstein v. Aetna Ins. Co., 375 Mass. 2.raw_text: Goldstein v. Aetna Ins. Co., 375 Mass. 271 (1978) — general negligence principles and duty analysis.
Goldstein v. Aetna Ins. Co., 375 Mass. 2.proposition: (Representative decisions interpreting duty, notice, breach, and causation principles applicable to slip-and-fall and premises cases; cited to illustrate governing Massachusetts law)
Goldstein v. Aetna Ins. Co., 375 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Goldstein v. Aetna Ins. Co., 375 Mass. 271 (1978), but rather a Massachusetts criminal case involving Stroud and issues of Miranda warnings, voluntariness of statements, trial procedure, and evidentiary rulings. It does not discuss premises liability, slip-and-fall law, or civil negligence duty, notice, breach, or causation principles. Accordingly, this opinion cannot properly be cited as representative authority on Massachusetts premises liability or slip-and-fall negligence law.
Goldstein v. Aetna Ins. Co., 375 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt:
The defendant retained as his counsel one Mr. Roger R. Pouliot, who, at the arraignment proceedings, filed an appearance in accordance with Rule 19 of the Superior Court (1954). Subsequent to the arraignment, the defendant was represented by another lawyer, who did not file an appearance. This lawyer represented the defendant in both the District and Superior Courts.

The defendant now argues that the judge committed reversible error by allowing the trial to proceed without requiring defense counsel to file an appearance. There is no substance to this argument.

Polay v. McMahon, 372 Mass. 706 (1977) \.raw_text: Polay v. McMahon, 372 Mass. 706 (1977) — duty and foreseeability in negligence actions.
Polay v. McMahon, 372 Mass. 706 (1977) \.proposition: (Representative decisions interpreting duty, notice, breach, and causation principles applicable to slip-and-fall and premises cases; cited to illustrate governing Massachusetts law)
Polay v. McMahon, 372 Mass. 706 (1977) \.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a criminal homicide case about evidentiary rulings, expert testimony, chain of custody, and prosecutorial argument in a murder trial. It does not concern premises liability, slip-and-fall, or the civil negligence concepts of duty, notice, breach, or causation in a property context. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that it is a representative Massachusetts decision on duty, notice, breach, and causation principles in slip-and-fall or premises cases.
Polay v. McMahon, 372 Mass. 706 (1977) \.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant appeals under G. L. c. 278, §§ 33A-33G, from his convictions on two indictments charging the crimes of murder. The indictments were tried together and they resulted in verdicts of guilty of murder in the first degree… We have examined all the alleged errors which were actually argued and we conclude that as to those there was no error.”

LeBlanc v. Dow, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1.raw_text: LeBlanc v. Dow, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1986) (unpublished order) — premises-liability inspection/no notice principles (illustrative of constructive notice jurisprudence).
LeBlanc v. Dow, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1.proposition: (Representative decisions interpreting duty, notice, breach, and causation principles applicable to slip-and-fall and premises cases; cited to illustrate governing Massachusetts law)
LeBlanc v. Dow, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns zoning and special-permit discretion for expansion of a nonconforming use, not premises-liability, slip-and-fall, inspection duties, or constructive notice. It discusses the standard of review of a board of appeals’ denial of a special permit, not duty, breach, notice, or causation principles in tort. Using this case as authority on Massachusetts premises-liability constructive notice jurisprudence is inaccurate and out of context.
LeBlanc v. Dow, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The denial of the special permit was within the discretion of the board. … However, ‘a court reviewing a decision of the board denying a permit does not possess the same discretionary power as does the board, and the decision of the board can only be disturbed if it is based ‘on a legally untenable ground’ ... or is ‘unreasonable, whimsical, capricious or arbitrary.’ … The ‘board may deny a [permit] even if the facts showed that a permit could be lawfully granted.’”

O'Connell v. D'Agostino, 31 Mass. App. C.raw_text: O'Connell v. D'Agostino, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 10 (1991) — notice and opportunity to remedy hazardous conditions.
O'Connell v. D'Agostino, 31 Mass. App. C.proposition: (Representative decisions interpreting duty, notice, breach, and causation principles applicable to slip-and-fall and premises cases; cited to illustrate governing Massachusetts law)
O'Connell v. D'Agostino, 31 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about ineffective assistance of counsel in connection with a motion to suppress a confession and the voluntariness of guilty pleas. It does not concern premises liability, slip-and-fall law, or the duty of landowners relating to notice and opportunity to remedy hazardous conditions. Therefore, it does not support the cited proposition regarding Massachusetts premises-liability principles.
O'Connell v. D'Agostino, 31 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was indicted on two counts of armed assault in a dwelling; two counts of burglary and armed assault; two counts of assault by means of a dangerous weapon; and two counts of armed robbery. ... The central question which this court is called upon to consider is whether the conduct of defense counsel in, allegedly, misrepresenting to the defendant that his motion to suppress a taped confession had been denied by the court fell so far below an objective standard of reasonableness as to constitute ineffective assistance of counsel...

Vasys v. Shaw's Supermarkets, Ltd., 26 M.raw_text: Vasys v. Shaw's Supermarkets, Ltd., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 187 (1988) — slip and fall, constructive notice analysis.
Vasys v. Shaw's Supermarkets, Ltd., 26 M.proposition: (Representative decisions interpreting duty, notice, breach, and causation principles applicable to slip-and-fall and premises cases; cited to illustrate governing Massachusetts law)
Vasys v. Shaw's Supermarkets, Ltd., 26 M.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a failed residential real estate closing and the construction and performance of a purchase and sale agreement (time of the essence, opportunity to record deed, breach by seller). It does not involve premises liability, slip-and-fall facts, or analysis of duty, notice, breach, or causation in the context of injuries on property. Citing it as a representative slip-and-fall / premises-liability decision is therefore inaccurate.
Vasys v. Shaw's Supermarkets, Ltd., 26 M.relevant_excerpt: "Construing the agreement as an integrated whole, giving reasonable effect to all of its provisions, we hold that implicit in the agreement was a requirement that the buyer would have an opportunity to record the deed prior to handing over bank checks or certified funds. ... In such circumstances, we hold that the seller was not free to declare a breach by the buyer and was required to accept a reasonable solution, e.g., postpone the closing until the next morning or allow the funds to be held in escrow."

Drake v. Old South Organization, Inc., 4.raw_text: Drake v. Old South Organization, Inc., 400 Mass. 1 (1987) — proximate cause and foreseeability in negligence.
Drake v. Old South Organization, Inc., 4.proposition: (Representative decisions interpreting duty, notice, breach, and causation principles applicable to slip-and-fall and premises cases; cited to illustrate governing Massachusetts law)
Drake v. Old South Organization, Inc., 4.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a § 1983/civil-rights case about warrantless searches and qualified immunity, not a negligence or premises-liability case. It does not discuss duty, notice, breach, causation, or any slip-and-fall/premises liability standards. Citing this case as a representative Massachusetts decision on slip-and-fall premises negligence law is inaccurate and not supported by the holding or reasoning.
Drake v. Old South Organization, Inc., 4.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff maintains that his constitutional rights were violated when the defendant searched his apartment without obtaining a warrant. Mincey v. Arizona, 437 U.S. 385 (1978) (concluding that there is no homicide scene exception to the warrant requirement). Nevertheless, the defendant contends that, under G. L. c. 38, § 6, and § 4.7 of the State police rules and regulations, he was not in charge of the investigation and thus was not in a position to obtain a warrant if one were required.

Ball v. Boston, 386 Mass. 492 (1982) \u2.raw_text: Ball v. Boston, 386 Mass. 492 (1982) — proprietor’s duty to invitees to keep premises safe.
Ball v. Boston, 386 Mass. 492 (1982) \u2.proposition: (Representative decisions interpreting duty, notice, breach, and causation principles applicable to slip-and-fall and premises cases; cited to illustrate governing Massachusetts law)
Ball v. Boston, 386 Mass. 492 (1982) \u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of the opinion is a criminal law dissent discussing application of the felony-murder rule to attempted extortion. It does not involve premises liability, slip-and-fall facts, a proprietor’s duty to invitees, or related concepts of notice, breach, or causation in a premises context. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition for which it is cited regarding Massachusetts premises liability law.
Ball v. Boston, 386 Mass. 492 (1982) \u2.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant went to the victim’s house armed with two loaded guns, a sawed-off shotgun, a large dog, a knife, and handcuffs in order to earn the money paid to him by Samson to collect an old gambling debt. In this setting, the victim was killed. It borders on the fanciful to deny that one of the natural and probable consequences of such attempted extortion is homicide... Hence, if such crimes as arson, burglary, robbery and larceny can be the basis for the application of the felony-murder rule, so too should the attempted extortion perpetrated in this case."

Bourne v. Boston, 373 Mass. 316 (1977) \.raw_text: Bourne v. Boston, 373 Mass. 316 (1977) — duty and reasonable care for persons on property.
Bourne v. Boston, 373 Mass. 316 (1977) \.proposition: (Representative decisions interpreting duty, notice, breach, and causation principles applicable to slip-and-fall and premises cases; cited to illustrate governing Massachusetts law)
Bourne v. Boston, 373 Mass. 316 (1977) \.case_name: Seppala & Aho Construction Co. v. Petersen
Bourne v. Boston, 373 Mass. 316 (1977) \.support_reasoning: This is a mortgage foreclosure case about a senior mortgagee’s duties of good faith and reasonable diligence toward a mortgagor and junior lienor, particularly concerning timing of foreclosure and adequacy of sale price. It does not involve premises liability, slip-and-fall facts, landowner/occupier duties to persons on property, or issues of notice, breach, and causation in that context. Citing it as a representative premises-liability/slip-and-fall decision would therefore be inaccurate and out of context.
Bourne v. Boston, 373 Mass. 316 (1977) \.relevant_excerpt: “We have frequently stated that the basic rule of law applicable to the foreclosure of real estate mortgages is that ‘a mortgagee in exercising a power of sale in a mortgage must act in good faith and must use reasonable diligence to protect the interests of the mortgagor.’… The precise question before us is whether Fidelco, by reason of its failure or refusal to foreclose the Ronrino mortgage promptly after the latter’s default, violated any duty owed to Seppala & Aho under the rule stated above.”

Allison v. Seacoast, Inc., 36 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal homicide case (murder/manslaughter, intoxication, malice instructions) and does not involve premises liability, slip-and-fall, store-owner duty, notice of dangerous conditions, or causation principles in that context. Allison v. Seacoast, Inc., 36 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: "At trial, the defendant did not deny that he fatally stabbed Raymond Sour at about 11 p.m. on July 1, 1990. Rather, he argued that his was a ‘classic case of manslaughter’ grounded on intoxication and provocation… Following a proper instruction on first degree murder and the capacity of proof of intoxication to reduce that crime to murder in the second degree, the judge gave the following instruction…"
